Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Children's Verbal Practices and Social Change

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Languages are key to both the organization and the transformation of communities. Particular language practices underpin some types of social relationships while also hindering others. As social relationships change, languages change in form and function, enabling new forms of sociality. The research supported by this award asks: What new ways of using indigenous and global languages are emerging today? And how are these new verbal practices enabling or preventing social change? Supervised by Dr. Miki Makihara of City University of New York, anthropology doctoral student Mariapaola Gritti will investigate these questions through a 15-month linguistic-ethnographic study of children's language practices in a village in American Samoan, a U.S. territory. This project will advance understanding of social change, expand existing linguistic methodologies, and clarify how language practices can underpin the sustainability of communities. It will also inform language policy. By documenting children's communicative practices, this project will enable mid- and long-term monitoring of one such policy: the Samoan-language instruction program currently piloted by the American Samoa Department of Education and aimed both to improve educational achievement and foster local language and culture maintenance in this U.S. territory.

American Samoa is an particularly appropriate site for this research because residents there face changes on multiple fronts, including, their environment, culture, forms of social organization, and possibilities for political participation. In addition, transnational kinship and economic relations, migration to Hawaii and the U.S. mainland, official use of English, attempts to introduce Samoan-language instruction in schools, and campaigns promoting Western pedagogical models all affect American Samoan ways of speaking Samoan and English. The intensity and simultaneity of these developments make the linguistic effects more salient for identification, documentation, and analysis, particularly in young children's speech. Therefore, Gritti will audio and video record and observe daily children's spontaneous social and linguistic interactions. She will survey these children's families and conduct ethnographic observation and interviews in the community. Her analysis of the language corpus will focus on two aspects of children's speech: (1) English borrowings into Samoan, which children use with variable frequency and phonology; and (2) personal pronouns, which children may use with a mixture of English or Samoan syntax and semantics. Employing the innovative concept of "semiotic potential," Gritti will monitor changes in frequency and effects of variants across situations, among children, and over developmental stages, to highlight how children's emerging grammar systems reflect their communicative needs, while also contributing to change in the language they speak. Finally, children's mimetic or play activities will be analyzed to identify children's ideas about the different variants, about Samoan and English, and about the changing world around them.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our ethnographic dissertation project investigated the experiences and understandings of social and political life formed by children in Manu'a, American Samoa. Manu'a children have grown up in a landscape dotted with ruins of abandoned houses, and aware that they too, like most of their families, will likely leave their island villages one day, likely for good. Since the late 1970s, Manu'ans have left their islands to go live in the US mainland or Hawai'i, and until today virtually all Manu'ans leave Manu'a after graduating high school. Of the very few who come back, many leave again later on, frustrated by chronically lacking infrastructure and services. And yet, the people we worked with in Manu'a were adamant that they did not want to live, let alone raise their children, elsewhere: they "believed" in Manu'a; they wanted to live the "free life" uniquely possible here. What about the children themselves? What understandings of relationships and sociality were they forming growing up in islands that so many had abandoned, and that for them too were going to be only temporary homes? How were they making sense of the social authority they were confronted with, particularly while this authority, which could not keep people in the village, or bring needed infrastructure to it, seemed to have limited purchase? And what social order and social understandings were they constructing, particularly with peers and others in their generation? 

We started from the assumption, which much linguistic anthropology research supports, that studying the face-to-face interactions in which these children participated would be key to answering these questions, not only due to the insights about socio-political experience that the children might make explicit in their conversations, but primarily due to the fact that the social reality that people experience is built, moment-by-moment, turn-by-turn, in face-to-face interactions. Fieldwork thus centered on participant observation and video-recording of the children's interactions across village, home, school settings. Interviews, short surveys and children's self-recordings were also conducted. 

Our first finding, which informed subsequent analysis, was that space played a central role as a social-interactional resource for the children. For example, while the community's overt social ideology played out in space, with directing younger people's movements in space as one typical way seniority-based authority was enacted, at the same time the children also drew on space to counter the effects of this overt ideology, for example by carefully monitoring older people's movements to limit the actual purchase of their authority. Indeed, we realized that the children were socializing each other to the specific uses and understandings of space which they presupposed in their interactions. These understandings were historically and culturally specific - the meanings of space as the setting of face-to-face interactions were interwoven with those of space as the village environment, one's family land, and the networks linking Manu'a to Manu'ans' other communities - and in turn mediated particular experiences and understandings of subjectivity, agency, power, sociality. Specifically, our analysis of interactions, against the background of children's and adults' commentaries on social life, revealed a nexus of two dialectical spatial understandings at the core of the children's socio-political and psycho-social experience: both power and subjectivity were defined through a relationship to space. While a defining feature of power, including seniority-based authority, was the capacity to control socially shared space, at the same time individual subjectivity was also experienced as grounded in a relationship with space, symbolically one's nurturing land. As the bedrock of personhood, this fundamental entitlement to space was at least partly independent of individuals' social relationships and thus limited the power which any individual could exert over others in social space. We realized that when drawing upon space as a counter-hierarchical resource, the children were drawing on an egalitarian pull away from the age-based hierarchy that marked their emerging psycho-socio-political understandings more generally and fundamentally. While aspects of this dialectic might have existed historically, our data also suggest that depopulation and outmigration might be amplifying its effects, thus also shaping the contemporary meanings of both hierarchical and egalitarian social logics.

Finally, our analyses show that space-based social understandings inform face-to-face interactions on many levels, from how children organized activity in collective space, to what verbal and nonverbal signs they preferably used, and whether Samoan or English. As with the socializing effects, these interactional patterns too have long-term effects. For example, we propose that the resilience of Samoan under extensive contact with English, striking when compared to other language-contact situations, can be explained through its spatial affordances as an interactional resource.

Besides contributing to various areas of anthropology, our findings about Manu'a children's socio-political experiences will be key to current and future children's welfare interventions in the territory; these interventions are currently based on psychosocial and sociopolitical models whose (Euro-American) sociocultural and political presuppositions are other than those Manu'a children live by.
